definitions: insert strips of fat into lean meat before cooking to add moisture and flavor
fill speech or writing with unnecessary embellishments or excessive details
examples: The chef decided to lard the roast with bacon strips
My grandmother would lard the turkey breast before roasting
He tends to lard his speeches with unnecessary quotations
The author larded the novel with too many subplots

definitions: engage in fun activities or mischievous behavior in a carefree playful manner
examples: The children were larking about in the garden all afternoon
We spent the weekend larking around at the beach

definitions: strike or beat with a whip or similar flexible instrument
tie or secure something tightly using rope cord or similar material
criticize or attack someone harshly with angry words
examples: The wind lashed the trees during the violent storm
Heavy rain lashed against the windows all night long
The sailors lashed the cargo to the deck securely
We need to lash these boxes together before transport
The critics lashed the director for his poor decisions
She lashed out at her colleagues during the meeting

definitions: catch an animal or object by throwing a rope formed into a large loop
examples: The cowboy managed to lasso the runaway calf quickly
She learned to lasso horses during her summer ranch vacation

definitions: close or secure a door gate or window using a simple fastening device
attach oneself firmly to something or someone either physically or emotionally
examples: Remember to latch the gate when you leave the yard
The door wouldn't latch properly because of the swollen wood
The baby latched onto her mother and wouldn't let go
He quickly latched onto the new concept during training

definitions: praise someone or something highly especially in a public or formal manner
examples: Critics lauded the film for its innovative cinematography techniques
The mayor lauded the volunteers for their community service efforts

definitions: wash dry and iron clothes bedding or other fabric items
conceal the origins of illegally obtained money by passing it through legitimate businesses
examples: She launders all the hotel linens twice a week
I need to launder these shirts before the business trip
The criminals laundered money through several offshore bank accounts
They were arrested for attempting to launder drug profits

definitions: give or spend something in large amounts without restraint often excessively
examples: She lavished attention on her grandchildren during their visit
The company lavished money on the new product launch

definitions: remove or drain away soluble substances from soil or other material by water passing through
examples: Heavy rainfall can leach nutrients from the garden soil
Chemicals from the landfill began to leach into groundwater

definitions: jump over someone or something by placing hands on their back while they crouch
advance by skipping intermediate stages or surpassing others in sequence
examples: Children love to leapfrog over each other during recess
The boys leapfrogged across the playground in a line
The startup leapfrogged established competitors with innovative technology
She leapfrogged several management levels to become vice president

definitions: grant or obtain use of property or equipment for specified time in exchange for payment
examples: We decided to lease the apartment for two years
The company leases office equipment rather than buying it

definitions: attach and control an animal using a rope or chain fastened to a collar
examples: Please leash your dog when walking in the park
The law requires owners to leash pets in public areas

definitions: habitually take advantage of others by draining their resources money or energy parasitically
examples: He tends to leech off his wealthy relatives constantly
Stop leeching off your roommate and pay your share

definitions: look at someone in an unpleasant way showing sexual interest or malicious intent
examples: The stranger leered at her from across the bar
He leered unpleasantly at the young women passing by

definitions: make something that was previously illegal acceptable or permissible by law
examples: Several countries have decided to legalise same-sex marriage recently
The government plans to legalise certain medicinal cannabis products

definitions: make something that was previously illegal acceptable or permissible by law
examples: Many states have voted to legalize recreational marijuana use
The movement aims to legalize assisted dying for terminally ill

definitions: create and pass laws through a legislative body or formal governmental process
examples: Congress has the power to legislate on interstate commerce
The committee will legislate new environmental protection standards tomorrow

definitions: make something legitimate acceptable or valid according to law or accepted standards
examples: The new policy will legitimise workers' rights to flexible hours
The court ruling legitimised the company's business practices completely

definitions: make something legitimate acceptable or valid according to law or accepted standards
examples: The referendum sought to legitimize the government's constitutional changes
Winning the award helped legitimize her work in the field

definitions: make something longer in distance duration or extent or become longer over time
examples: The tailor can lengthen your pants by two inches
Days begin to lengthen noticeably after the winter solstice

definitions: reduce in amount intensity degree or size or become less than before
examples: Taking this medication should lessen your pain within hours
The storm's intensity began to lessen by early morning

definitions: move or force something using a rigid bar as a mechanical advantage tool
examples: He managed to lever the heavy rock out of place
Use this crowbar to lever open the stuck window

definitions: use something to maximum advantage especially to gain power influence or achieve goals
examples: The company plans to leverage its brand recognition globally
She leveraged her connections to secure the important contract

definitions: rise and hover in the air without visible support appearing to defy gravity
examples: The magician appeared to levitate several feet above stage
In the dream, she could levitate above the trees

definitions: impose and collect a tax fee or fine by legal or official authority
examples: The government plans to levy new taxes on luxury goods
The court may levy fines against violators of the ordinance

definitions: establish communication and maintain cooperation between different groups departments or organizations
examples: She will liaise between the marketing and design teams regularly
The officer liaises with local community groups about safety concerns

definitions: publish false and damaging written statements about someone that harm their reputation
examples: The newspaper was sued for libeling the politician repeatedly
Be careful not to libel anyone in your blog posts

definitions: set someone or something free from imprisonment oppression or restrictive situation
examples: Allied forces worked to liberate occupied territories during wartime
The therapy helped liberate her from years of anxiety

definitions: give official permission or legal authority to do use or own something
examples: The city will licence food trucks in designated areas only
The board must licence all new medical practitioners annually

definitions: pass the tongue over something to taste moisten or clean it
defeat someone or something completely in competition or overcome a problem
examples: The cat loves to lick her fur clean daily
Children often lick ice cream cones in hot weather
Our team managed to lick the opposition in yesterday's game
I think we've finally licked the problem with the software

definitions: reduce the weight or load of something to make it easier to carry
make something brighter in color shade or illumination than before
make a mood situation or atmosphere less serious tense or oppressive
examples: We need to lighten the boat's load before sailing
Can you help me lighten this heavy backpack please
The sun began to lighten the eastern sky beautifully
She decided to lighten her hair for the summer
His jokes always lighten the mood during stressful meetings
Try to lighten up and enjoy the party tonight

definitions: transfer cargo or goods from ship to shore using a flat-bottomed barge
examples: Workers will lighter the cargo to the dock tomorrow morning
They had to lighter supplies to the remote island

definitions: stretch and warm up muscles before physical activity to increase flexibility
examples: Athletes should limber up before starting intense training sessions
The dancers limbered at the barre for fifteen minutes

definitions: walk with difficulty or irregularly due to injury pain or physical disability
examples: He began to limp after twisting his ankle badly
The injured dog limped slowly back to its owner

definitions: remain in a place longer than necessary often reluctant to leave
examples: Guests lingered at the party until well past midnight
The sweet perfume lingered in the room for hours

definitions: apply colored cosmetic to the lips for decoration or color enhancement
examples: She carefully lipsticked her lips before the important meeting
The makeup artist lipsticked the model in bright red

definitions: convert assets or property into cash by selling especially to pay debts
eliminate or kill someone especially as planned assassination or execution
examples: The company had to liquidate its assets during bankruptcy
They decided to liquidate their stock portfolio before retirement
The spy thriller featured agents trying to liquidate enemy operatives
The dictator ordered forces to liquidate political opponents secretly

definitions: speak with a speech pattern where s sounds are pronounced like th
examples: The young child still lisps when saying certain words
She lisped slightly when nervous during public speaking events

definitions: drop or leave trash garbage or waste carelessly in public places
give birth to multiple offspring at once especially for animals
examples: Please don't litter in the park or on streets
Tourists who litter the beach face heavy fines
Our cat littered five healthy kittens last night
The dog is expected to litter within the week

definitions: spend time in a lazy idle way avoiding work or useful activity
examples: He tends to loaf around the house on weekends
Stop loafing and help me with these chores please

definitions: throw or hit a ball slowly in a high arc through the air
examples: She lobbed the tennis ball over her opponent's head
The pitcher decided to lob an easy ball to the batter

definitions: restrict something to a particular area or limit its spread
adapt a product or service to meet local language culture or preferences
examples: Doctors worked to localize the infection before it spread
The fire department managed to localize the blaze quickly
Software companies must localize their products for different markets
We need to localize our marketing campaign for Asia

definitions: provide temporary accommodation or stay somewhere as a paying guest
become firmly stuck or embedded in a particular position or place
present or make a formal complaint or appeal to an authority
examples: Students can lodge with local families during the semester
We decided to lodge at a small inn near the lake
A piece of food lodged in his throat causing distress
The bullet lodged dangerously close to his spine
She plans to lodge a complaint with the manager today
Citizens can lodge appeals against planning decisions officially

definitions: hit or kick a ball high into the air in a gentle arc
examples: The golfer lofted the ball perfectly onto the green
He lofted the soccer ball over the defensive wall

definitions: appear as a vague large shape often in threatening or frightening way
examples: Dark clouds loomed on the horizon before the storm
Financial problems loom large in their future planning discussions

definitions: make something less tight firm or fixed than it was before
make rules restrictions or controls less strict severe or rigid
examples: Could you help me loosen this jar lid please
The mechanic needs to loosen the bolts before removal
The school decided to loosen its dress code policy
The government may loosen travel restrictions next month

definitions: steal goods from shops or buildings during war riot or civil disorder
examples: Rioters began to loot stores during the civil unrest
Soldiers were forbidden to loot homes in occupied territories

definitions: cut off branches or twigs from a tree or shrub with quick strokes
examples: The gardener will lop the overgrown branches this afternoon
We need to lop these dead limbs before they fall

definitions: run or move with a long bounding stride in relaxed easy manner
examples: The horse loped gracefully across the open meadow
He loped along the trail enjoying the mountain scenery

definitions: lie sit or stand in a relaxed lazy way without apparent purpose
examples: Teenagers love to lounge on the couch after school
We spent the afternoon lounging by the hotel pool
